content.raw: To respond to @tkoolen's comment on BDI controller:  The purpose of adding the ability to adjust cfm damping dynamically is to make it easier for teams, and I updated my comment in issue #194 to be more specific about the simulation noise induced dynamic instability, which is not the driving force for the new feature introduced in pull request #248, and that we are not changing the bounds as [posted in the user guide](http://gazebosim.org/wiki/DRC/UserGuide#ROS_Services).
content.html: To respond to @tkoolen's comment on BDI controller: The purpose of adding the ability to adjust cfm damping dynamically is to make it easier for teams, and I updated my comment in issue #194 to be more specific about the simulation noise induced dynamic instability, which is not the driving force for the new feature introduced in pull request #248, and that we are not changing the bounds as posted in the user guide.

content.raw:
This pull request is about offering the capability to set CFM damping via a ROS service call. 

Please use issue #194 for further discussion about what the limits should or should not be, and also use that forum to discuss the possibility of including Chris's Method 1 as a future pull-request.
content.html:
This pull request is about offering the capability to set CFM damping via a ROS service call.

Please use issue #194 for further discussion about what the limits should or should not be, and also use that forum to discuss the possibility of including Chris's Method 1 as a future pull-request.

pullrequest.title: per issue #194, alternative solution, add ROS service, allowing user to change joint damping with hard coded per joint bounds

content.raw:
Let me first respond to Steven Peters comment. LQR design is a good way to spread gains across joints. For us, it sets the ankle joint
damping to about 100, and damping elsewhere to be less. So yes, you can spread the gains. Reasonable design techniques set the ankle damping to be about 100. Stabilization is not the same thing as eliminating sway. Very low ankle damping gains can stabilize the robot. But sway puts the COM close to the edges of the support polygon, increasing the risk of falling over with disturbances.

To Twan Koolen: CFM Damping is just another way to implement damping, which seems to be better than the current way.

The real problem we are trying to solve is that the velocity is very noisy, and our ability to do stuff from ROS is severly limited by the delay and dropouts (which worst case reduce our controller bandwidth compared to a Gazebo plugin by about a factor of 5, even with the SYNC mechanism, since we have to handle the worst case drop out).

How do we make the PD control on the simulator useful, given the large velocity noise?

Method 1: Implement the D gain as CFM damping, controllable on each tick. I really like this solution. People who want low damping
can have it. People who want high damping can have it. CFM damping seems to be a much better implementation of damping that
using SetForce(), in terms of actually being an energy sink.

Method 2: Implement user settable filterering (a crude form of state estimation) as part of the local PD control.

By the way, with joint torque control on our hydraulic humanoid robot we can make the damping very small, or even negative, as well as making it quite large. So arguments that CFM damping values have something to do with how the robot actually works are a little suspect, or the robot has crappy joint torque control (which I doubt).
content.html:
Let me first respond to Steven Peters comment. LQR design is a good way to spread gains across joints. For us, it sets the ankle joint damping to about 100, and damping elsewhere to be less. So yes, you can spread the gains. Reasonable design techniques set the ankle damping to be about 100. Stabilization is not the same thing as eliminating sway. Very low ankle damping gains can stabilize the robot. But sway puts the COM close to the edges of the support polygon, increasing the risk of falling over with disturbances.

To Twan Koolen: CFM Damping is just another way to implement damping, which seems to be better than the current way.

The real problem we are trying to solve is that the velocity is very noisy, and our ability to do stuff from ROS is severly limited by the delay and dropouts (which worst case reduce our controller bandwidth compared to a Gazebo plugin by about a factor of 5, even with the SYNC mechanism, since we have to handle the worst case drop out).

How do we make the PD control on the simulator useful, given the large velocity noise?

Method 1: Implement the D gain as CFM damping, controllable on each tick. I really like this solution. People who want low damping can have it. People who want high damping can have it. CFM damping seems to be a much better implementation of damping that using SetForce(), in terms of actually being an energy sink.

Method 2: Implement user settable filterering (a crude form of state estimation) as part of the local PD control.

By the way, with joint torque control on our hydraulic humanoid robot we can make the damping very small, or even negative, as well as making it quite large. So arguments that CFM damping values have something to do with how the robot actually works are a little suspect, or the robot has crappy joint torque control (which I doubt).

content.raw:
Could it be that the other robot joints are too stiff? It should be possible for damping at other joints to assist; it doesn't all have to come from the ankle.

Consider an inverted [Acrobot](http://webdocs.cs.ualberta.ca/~sutton/book/ebook/node110.html) as an analogy to Atlas. The acrobot has not torque at its fixed joint (analogous to Atlas's ankle joint), but there are control algorithms that can stabilize the Acrobot using the actuator at the middle joint (analogous to Atlas's hip, knees, etc.).
content.html:
Could it be that the other robot joints are too stiff? It should be possible for damping at other joints to assist; it doesn't all have to come from the ankle.

Consider an inverted Acrobot as an analogy to Atlas. The acrobot has not torque at its fixed joint (analogous to Atlas's ankle joint), but there are control algorithms that can stabilize the Acrobot using the actuator at the middle joint (analogous to Atlas's hip, knees, etc.).

content.raw:
The problem I was referring to is pitch sway while standing. We don't experience any, despite the low CFM damping.

I didn't understand at first that you're planning to use this parameter as a damping gain that is changed dynamically in your controller. Is this the idea of the pull request? My understanding was that the CFM damping would be a parameter that could be set only once at startup and needs to be configurable because apparently the BDI walking algorithm doesn't walk without it being set to a huge value (i.e. a hack to get things to work).

I get that you want to get better performance out of the local position control loop, but is it fair to teams that don't do position control and have to live with the crappy velocity signals? Changing the CFM damping once at startup could be the equivalent of modifying the physical robot to add more viscous damping to the joints, but it wouldn't be possible to change the mechanical viscous damping on the fly.
content.html:
The problem I was referring to is pitch sway while standing. We don't experience any, despite the low CFM damping.

I didn't understand at first that you're planning to use this parameter as a damping gain that is changed dynamically in your controller. Is this the idea of the pull request? My understanding was that the CFM damping would be a parameter that could be set only once at startup and needs to be configurable because apparently the BDI walking algorithm doesn't walk without it being set to a huge value (i.e. a hack to get things to work).

I get that you want to get better performance out of the local position control loop, but is it fair to teams that don't do position control and have to live with the crappy velocity signals? Changing the CFM damping once at startup could be the equivalent of modifying the physical robot to add more viscous damping to the joints, but it wouldn't be possible to change the mechanical viscous damping on the fly.

content.raw:
It is not clear what your note (or my previous note) refers to. So let me try to fix that. We would like to make the local PD control on the simulator machine useful. The PD controller on the simulator machine doesn't use a state estimator, so state estimation is irrelevant. It just multiplies the D gain times the raw velocity signal (or numerically differentiated position signal, which is just as noisy). A gain of about 100 pumps too much noise into the robot through the torque command. If you are suggesting the ankle pitch gain can be significantly less than 100, here is a counter-argument (which boils down to what time constant you can tolerate).

A local linearization of whatever you do that is smooth boils down to a PD controller, and we can relate the damping and the time constant for a critically damped system: damping = 2 x mass x natural_frequency
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Damping_ratio

crude argument:
mass of robot is about 100,
height of COM is about 1.
moment of inertia of robot about ankle axis is about 100,
damping = 2 x moi x w.
For w = 1r/s (1/(2pi)Hz), required damping is 200.

slightly more refined argument:
mass of robot without feet is 95.3057,
com_position relative to ankle is
    0.0153   -0.0897    0.8251,
I_yy = 12 (estimate),
moi_ankle_y = I_yy + mass * (l_x^2 + l_z^2) =
12 + 95.3057*(0.0153^2 + 0.8251^2) =
77.
For w = 1r/s (1/(2pi)Hz), required damping is 154,

A 1r/s time constant is really too low.
content.html:
It is not clear what your note (or my previous note) refers to. So let me try to fix that. We would like to make the local PD control on the simulator machine useful. The PD controller on the simulator machine doesn't use a state estimator, so state estimation is irrelevant. It just multiplies the D gain times the raw velocity signal (or numerically differentiated position signal, which is just as noisy). A gain of about 100 pumps too much noise into the robot through the torque command. If you are suggesting the ankle pitch gain can be significantly less than 100, here is a counter-argument (which boils down to what time constant you can tolerate).

A local linearization of whatever you do that is smooth boils down to a PD controller, and we can relate the damping and the time constant for a critically damped system: damping = 2 x mass x natural_frequency http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Damping_ratio

crude argument: mass of robot is about 100, height of COM is about 1. moment of inertia of robot about ankle axis is about 100, damping = 2 x moi x w. For w = 1r/s (1/(2pi)Hz), required damping is 200.

slightly more refined argument: mass of robot without feet is 95.3057, com_position relative to ankle is 0.0153 -0.0897 0.8251, I_yy = 12 (estimate), moi_ankle_y = I_yy + mass * (l_x^2 + l_z^2) = 12 + 95.3057*(0.0153^2 + 0.8251^2) = 77. For w = 1r/s (1/(2pi)Hz), required damping is 154,

A 1r/s time constant is really too low.

content.raw:
Why put an upper limit on CFM damping? The ankle pitch joints need around 100 to stop pitch sway while standing.
The velocity signal is way too noisy to do this with velocity feedback.
Chris
content.html: Why put an upper limit on CFM damping? The ankle pitch joints need around 100 to stop pitch sway while standing. The velocity signal is way too noisy to do this with velocity feedback. Chris
